Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit comprising an inductor \(L\), capacitor \(C\), and resistor \(R\), governing the charge \(Q\) on the capacitor. The dynamics of \(Q\) are described by the second-order differential equation \(L \ddot{Q} + R \dot{Q} + \frac{Q}{C} = 0\). We examine the effect of a sinusoidal voltage source \(V(t) = V_0 \sin(\omega t)\) introduced into the circuit at different times.

If an abrupt change in resistance \(R\) to a new value \(R'\) occurs at time \(t = t_1\), does the future behavior of \(Q(t)\) for \(t > t_1\) depend only on the new resistance \(R'\) and not on the initial \(R\)?
Explanation: The system’s future behavior depends not just on the instantaneous resistance \(R'\) but also on past charge and current conditions, maintained through \(Q\) and \(\dot{Q}\) at \(t_1\), which in turn are influenced by the earlier resistance \(R\), inductor \(L\), and capacitor \(C\).
